title: Which presidential candidate will win Ohio?
preds: While Ohio has had a long standing reputation as a swing state, it has trended more reliably red for the past several elections. Based on the demographics in Ohio outside of the major city centers (largely white and rural), I think that gives Trump the edge in the Buckeye state

While it seems that Biden has a lead in the United States as a whole right now, Ohio tends to lean Republican more than Democrat. An important consideration is that while the polling strategies and methodologies have improved since 2016, it seems that key battleground states were predicted impressively wrong. So while the polls are showing a close race, I think that we have to factor in that there is a strong Republican lean in Ohio that has been overlooked before. That is why I am giving an edge to Trump over Biden

On eve of election, looks like it will be close, with slight Trump win in the end. The latest poll by a widely-regarded good pollster actually found Biden up by 1, although with 7% of OH voters undecided: https://emersonpolling.reportablenews.com/pr/super-poll-sunday-polling-in-the-midwest-shows-biden-ahead-in-michigan-and-tight-races-in-ohio-and-iowa
This one could go either way but an ever slight edge to Trump here.

Dem early in person voting, traditionally one of the strongest parts of their GOTV operation is a dumpster fire.   Mail in voting mostly cannibalizing their high propensity E-day base.  Ohio has bucked the national trend of increasing blue margins and gone the opposite way, having lopsided Republican victories in 2014, 2016, and electing all save one Republican statewide offices in the blue wave of 2018.   The margin of victories in 2014 and 2016 for Republican candidates were shockingly large in comparison to many other purple states in 2014/2016.   Stagnant demography, mediocre but not terrible job prospects, and exporting of college educated youth to trendy coastal or sunbelt cities makes the education gap less important.   Lastly, the Democrats have spent far too little time and money speaking to non college educated white women while fighting tooth and nail for every upscale chardonnay mom.
Ohio is tied but demographics suggest Biden could win here.
Trump has a slight lead in Ohio. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/ohio/
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Looks real tight, think silent Trumpers will tip him over the line though.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Ohio by 5.5 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 51.3% for trump to Biden's 44.8%. Seven day momentum was in trump's favor, improving his position by 0.9%. But this state is likely to end up as a flip of the coin result that will be very difficult to predict.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Rising Covid rates in Iowa give Biden an every so slight edge.

Trump has pulled ads in Ohio with three weeks left until the election to conserve cash for other states he is losing worse in. While this state remains a toss-up, any bump Trump gets will not be due to his own campaigning and will instead likely be tied to things like COVID updates, scandals, and economic changes.

In 2018 Ohio elected a republican Governor. The last poll that wikipedia shows had him 5 points behind. He won by 4 points. 2016 Trump won Ohio by 8 points. Libertarian party got 3. Probably not because of Gary Johnson. Rightwing people who were not sure about Trump I presume. Will they vote for Jorgensen this time? For Biden who says he will raise taxes and do the Green New Deal? No. Most of these people will vote Trump.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Ohio by 5.5 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 50.9% for trump to Biden's 45.4%. Seven day momentum was in trump's favor, improving his position by 0.85%. For now even though Biden leads in polling averages and forecasts the momentum indicates a potential for trump to retake lost ground. But this state is likely to end up as a flip of the coin result that will be very difficult to predict.
Polling has recently tilted towards Biden, but only slightly.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)
Biden's polling is continuing to get better in Ohio. Feels genuinely as toss-up as they come.
Taking 2016 polling bias into account I'm going to guess a slight Trump lean.

Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 46% for trump to Biden's 50.65%. Seven day momentum was in trump's favor, improving his position by 0.78%. For now even though Biden leads in polling averages and forecasts the momentum indicates a potential for trump to retake lost ground.   But this state is likely to end up as a flip of the coin result that will be very difficult to predict.

It's a very tight race in Ohio but Biden is the kind of guy who should do well in Ohio.  Biden is doing well with lesser educated whites in other states, particularly Iowa. So he should do well in Ohio too.   In 2016 Trump won Texas by 9 points, Iowa by 10 points, Ohio by 8 points and Georgia by 5 points.  This year all of those seats are competitive, they are all statistically tied,  with Biden leading in all but Texas.  I think the upcoming debates will benefit Biden. Historically, debates have rarely been game changers.  But this might be the exception a la Carter v Reagan.  And I think Trump will become increasingly erratic in the coming weeks and that won't help Trump with the marginal voter.  His scandals will continue to mount.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Ohio by 5.5 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 49.75% for trump to Biden's 45.25%.

I think POTUS's lies and empty promises have lost their magic: the "economy", i.e. workers and their employers are on the brink not in spite of DjT being incumbent, but because of him. Apart from his paid cheering crowd in the hangars of Vandalia, OH, other voters in Ohio might see this clearer.

This one is closer than I have it rated. Ohio is a ball of confusion. Biden up in recent Rasmussen poll but over time Trump has held a slight lead. https://www.cleveland.com/open/2020/09/donald-trump-leads-joe-biden-in-tracking-poll-of-ohio-likely-voters.html

I checked the source polls that 538 aggregates.  Many of the lower quality polls have the two candidates tied or with a slight edge the Republican Party candidate.  When filtering to only A and A+ polls the Democratic Party candidate has a an edge.  Also, filtering for only Likely and Registered voters leaves the Democratic Party candidate with a small edge.

The crowd understates the odds of Trump in Ohio. I know the polling average shows Trump with a slim lead and Rasmussen showed Biden ahead, but recent history is that Ohio's voters are for whatever reason hard to accurately poll. 
https://radio.wosu.org/post/ohios-2018-election-results-look-lot-trumps-2016-results
Look at the statewide races in 2018. Ignore Senator because the GOP candidate who should have run, John Kasich, declined to do so, and it was a popular Dem incumbent. Look at the other statewide races such as governor, secretary of state, etc. The GOP ran the table statewide!  Now look at the polls leading up to the election: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/ohio/  Should have been a Democratic win, but it wasn't. I don't know why, and I don't know if pollsters are correcting for this adequately, but in the Midwest the GOP voters are hard to poll and the question of who will actually turn out seems to be more difficult than in most other parts of the US.
Close and fluid polls.  Updating on 9/8 polls.
FiveThirtyEight model shows Trump with a slight advantage in Ohio but there is still a long way to go. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/ohio/
Slight edge to Biden still due to support from independent and suburban women voters.
Moving closer to the crowd.  Trump seems to be polling up 5%.

2016 Voted for DT: 51.7%
GOP state win: 60% (last 10)
DT 538: 61%
Crowd: 55%
Gotta start somewhere.  No republican has won without winning Ohio.
Decreasing chances for dems a bit - although no more recent polling data available - still showing Biden up +2.3 on RCP avg.
Per FiveThirtyEight, Biden has only been above Trump by 3-5% points since April, and the numbers have been closing over the past 30-60 days.
Ohio follows the trend of swinging red.

https://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/trump-goodyear-boycott-diversity-training Here's a little thought experiment:  Imagine, if you will, a large company in Ohio's fifth-largest city that manufactures an extremely popular and vitally necessary automobile part, and whose workers belong to a rather strong labour union based in the second-largest city in Pennsylvania. Now imagine you are a presidential candidate who badly needs to carry both Ohio and Pennsylvania.  You hear a report that this company is telling its employees they can't wear bits of your campaign gear.  Without ascertaining the facticity of this report, you advise everyone in the United States not to buy this company's products any more.  (You have momentarily forgotten--if you ever knew--that people vote but hats, by and large, do not.) Do you suppose this tantrum will have a favourable or an unfavourable effect on your chances of carrying Ohio?  Now let's not always see the same hands....
Polls are looking slightly better for Trump in Ohio - plus new forecasts seem to give Trump the edge - so I'll give him the edge too!

As the economic and labor data have been better than expected, Biden's lead in Ohio has all but collapsed. I still think that we will see more headwinds as the sugar rush from $18+tn global stimulus and QE will wear off, but I am revising my numbers down sharply in light of the almost coin flip odds others are seeing.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/ohio/
Updating to reflect recent polling showing the two candidates virtually neck and neck.

Outside View:
~~~~~~~~~~~
Trump is Tied or up by 0.5 points in Ohio. The base rate will then be 55% averaged with the crowd forecast which is 60%. Which would then make this 57.5 percent.  ~~~~~~~~~~

When you read up on some old polls on the issues. Ohions believe that Biden would do better on the Coronavirus and would do better in Race Relations. And this was from the Fox News as well. However, they view that Trump would be  better at the economy, which is a thing that is relevant to the upcoming election.  When reading through the YouGov poll, the largest thing that is facing ohio people is the Coronavirus. Also, people hate Trump more than they hate Biden. Ergo I will give Biden a slight lead 52%.  1. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Vbmv7EXnwqeubTuvBYNiBvq565sOxi_9/view
Morning Consult poll just released yesterday has Trump +3: https://morningconsult.com/form/july-presidential-battleground-state-polling/

The last time Ohio backed a loser was Kennedy '60 and Trump won by 7 points in 2016, larger than either of Obama's wins. Given that the two candidates are polling almost identically at the moment, Trump comes away with an incumbent advantage that may determine it.
Based on recent polls it is currently a challenge for Trump to win but not impossible.
Amazed that we are this close in OH, current RCP avg showing Biden up +2.3, this has pushed me closer to 50/50.

Candidates are trading places in Ohio right now according to Qunnipiac. [1] I suspect that as the President's approval ratings worsen, the situation will change. [1] https://poll.qu.edu/ohio/release-detail?ReleaseID=3665
Overwhelming white working class who continue to feel abandoned will carry the day.
Demographics, very popular conservative radio.  Howver, it will be more diificult for Trump than if the virus had not come to be,
Its a tie as of now.
Biden will win in every Rust Belt state. Workers love him, and they now know for certain Trump could not care less about them or their families.
Biden +2.5 on 538's tracker, but within the margin of error

Ohio has historically been representative of the whole nation in its decision. Given the strong indication of the national polls in Democrat's candidate, I slide the bar in their direction slightly. Also, the poor federal governance about the pandemic does not help republican votes.

Hard with this forecast because basically (in line with other forecasts) saying the candidate will win Ohio and won't win election ... not happened for v.long time. Biden will be competitive but think DT will just edge.
National sentiment change can be seen in Ohio polling too
My new 2020 election forecast just launched at plusminusforecasts.com!
Very little separating the candidates and no clear trend in polls. Trump has slight advantage due to incumbency.

It's neck and neck even while Trump is 10% behind nationally. The final stretch will reinforce partisanship and push some voters who have left Trump in the last couple of months back into his column which should be enough to win him Ohio.
Ohio has become a very reddish state as of late. However, recent polling suggests Biden has a real shot at taking it. Considering Trump is defacto throwing the race now, Ohio is very much in play.
Polls shifting in favour of Biden and so am narrowing the odds in Biden's favour.
Unlike Pennsylvania, the frustrated blue collar workers are still searching for someone to fight for them and their perception is the President is a fighter and on their side.
Still very close. Momentum with Biden but not enough

Ohio is the very definition of a battleground state. I believe the democratic machine gets people registered and to the polls. This state is too important to not spend the time and money on. The state may also turn its back on Trump and give Biden and easy win.

Tanenbaum and Bates' poll of polls has Ohio at 45/43 (D/R). https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/tipping_point.html
----
Unfortunately, Ohio's 2012 and 2016 opinion polls [listed at Wikipedia] suggest a 45/43 split simply means they're undecided and many Republican (white, male, non-college educated) U-boot voters (100 – [ 45+43=88] = 12) do play a role.  Republicans seem to have pushed Dr Amy Acton out of office, a symbolic win on the COVID-19 issue.
The vast majority of opinions polls show that Joe Biden is ahead in the polls by a small margin. This could easily change closer to election night. Answer will possibly change closer to the date.
Trump will put all his eggs in one basket as the elections near. And it will Ohio to show that he is high in polls there to show that he will the working man.

A classic tossup state. Mike DeWine has won points with his handline of COVID, but Trump's promise to bring back jobs from overseas has largely failed to come about. If urban and suburban turnout is good, Biden wins. If rural voters turn out, Trump has a better chance. Kasich could play a role here if he abandons Trump.
Ohio is very swing.  I would go for Trump if it were not for the response to the death of George Floyd. Currently this nudges Biden and the Democrats ahead
It is too far out to reliably decide how Ohio will go. Key factors still in play are the continuing epidemic and the protests. I don’t think Citizens have made a decision yet.

Ohio is lately very Red. If Trump loses Ohio it will mean he's lost the election by a wide margin. A possibility, especially with Biden's rust belt appeal. But not likely enough, enough white non-college educated voters to favor Trump.
This will be too close to call until the very end of counting.

Polls indicate voters in Ohio are more decided this year, than in 2020.  Trump won by 8% in 2016, so will be tough to swing this state to Biden in 2020.  The winds favor Biden nationally, but Ohio will be close.
Poverty and racism don’t play well

45/44 split on 270 to vote but I know that Trump has OHIO as the riots will cause a backlash and old people vote no matter what they have nothing else to do and gez Z has attention span of a chiwawa on ritalin
Barring unforeseen circumstances there's no way that Trump wins more then a few states like Tennessee.
Ohio is very blue collar, and is the center of the rust belt. Trump tells those people what they want to hear.
Taking an average of my previous forecast, the new economist model, and the JHK model.
Ohio has gone with the Winner since LBJ.  Ohio politics is dominated by the Republicans. So giving a slight edge in the baseline estimate to the Republican candidate for now.

My personal feeling is to lean republican, because I think Joe Biden will get "beaten" in the debates, but I'm reacting to 538's news that Biden has a strong lead, and I'm sort of averaging my prior and Nate Cohns forecast.
Lot of unrest out there. change candidate

There have been small bounces back and forth since the beginning of COVID [1]. 538's latest poll is from Fox, showing Biden up by 2 points [2]. This is the only poll in June. Ohio does not have a senate race this year. 12 of the 16 house districts are currently held by republicans [3], a few of which are being polled and show the republicans in the lead for this fall [4]. Overall, the above, plus the incumbent advantage, leans republican. Putting it there for now. This may change since the three highest populated cities (proper, not metro) in Ohio are 40-60% POC, so there may be more activation with the recent protests [5,6,7]. [7] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati

It will be a close call. People, Americans are for the most part party line with little give, hardliners, and ADHD, with triggering events being the latest information in the news - the world has followed suit.
Trump has consolidated Ohio due to cultural factors.
Trump losing Ohio would mean he is loSing badly but that seems a real prospect.  However a close election would imply Trump wins Ohio and this remains a strong prospect too.  So toss up.
turnout in Cleveland, Cincinnati, Columbus crucial
Ohio is still a red state and it is hard to imagine Biden generating enough enthusiasm to flip the state.
I need to ride this out a bit.
